div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,361] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, December 5th, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said.Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamersfor Marceille, Gibralter, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Saidafter the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindle Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before
The express steamer usually reaches Brindial on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving to London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindial or via Marseille.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or MArseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcotta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOB (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
An Unjustifiable Scare

The Propietors, jewelers, an ironmongers of Mousky, Clot Bey, and Esbekieh quarters of Cairo have come into ine with the rest on the subject of Sunday closing. Last Sunday was the first of the new order of things and, as some slight disturbances had occurred on previous Sunday, some mounted police were told off to see that order was preserved. These precautionary measures gave rise to some astonishing rumuors, the nature of which may be understood from the following specimen:
Q. What are the shawishes doing here?
A. The Sultan has sent 500 mulluhs to preach a Jehad here against the Christians and the police are looking for them.

We gather that Cairo has been less perturbed than Alexandria, which has accepted (among other things) a massacre at Tantah, a religious riot at Damietta- an echo this of the Samanoud affair, megaphonically enlarged- and an anti Christian demonstration near the Abassieh barracks- what a place to chose!- the news of which, strangely enough, reached our commercial capital on Sunday, but had not arrived at the Ministries on Monday afternoon. We must confess to a certain disgust at hearing absurd stories of this circulating among Europeans, particularly among our Greek fellow citizens. The Greeks of Egypt have shown such financial enterprise and business acumen that it comes as a shock to find men whom we were accustomed to regard as level headed and intelligent betraying a nervousness that can only be qualified as object, on the strength of some absurd rumuors.

Meantime, Mustapha Pasha Kamal has spoken ex-cathedral. We are to have no revolution, not a single broker is to suffer,-except those who sold out at a loss on hearing that the berbereen were about to sack Cairo. We knew this all along, but the Pasha’s statement will no doubt reassure that more timid. As for the Egyptian Press, with one or two exceptions, it has behaved with proper calm and dignity. Amrica is too far for the scare headline to have reached us, and the majority of the European population of Egypt possesses a sense of humour. For the minority we have only the Homeric exhortation, ”Be men, my friends, remember your dashing courage”.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, TUESDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1905.
div.p: FEAR OF CIVIL WAR
St.Petersburg, December 4.

Most elaborate precautions are being taken in view of a feared outbreak of the troops. The Marine Infantry have been disarmed on account of thieir sympathy with the revolution.Quick firers have been trained on the Horse Guards barracks. All who can are leaving the country. Finance and commerce are paralyzed.

The engine drivvers of St. Petersburg expresses bring the Russian news of Reuter's Agent twice daily to the German frontier, whence it is telegraphed. But an impending general railway strike threatens to cut off this means of communication. Several Embasies have received the news of militairy outbreaks in the Baltic provinces, particularly at Reval, where the reservists are in open revolt. (Reuter)
London, December 4
Comminucation has been momentarily obtained with ccertain isolated parts of Russia today, but was immediately broken again.

The mutinous conduct of the troops has led to disorders at Kharkoff and at Kishinoff for the same cause as the disturbances at Kieff where there were 70 killed and 300 wounded. Martial law has been proclaimed.

Saturday's despatches from St. Petersburg present a calamitous picture of turmoil and public alarm. There is much talk of a military dictatorship, but the loyalty of the troops is questioned, and an attempt to carry out the project would probably end in civil war.
The suffering of families of strikers is daily becoming more intense. Robberis in the streets in broad daylight ar ecommon. No letters have been distributed since Tuesday. (Reuter)
Panic on Pari Bourse
Paris, Deccember 4
Further heavy falls in Russian securities caused a collapse verging on a panic at the Bourse. (Reuter)
GEARGETOWN RIOT ENDED
Georgetown, December 4
The cruisers have arrived and the riot is at an end, without casualties amond the whites. (Reuter)
FRANCE AND RUSSIA
Paris, December 4

Questioned in the Chamber of Deputies regarding the words employed by the Socialists on Friday, M Rouvier condemned the anti militarist propaganda. He asserted that an immence majority of Frenchmen remained faithful to Russian friendship and the alliance. His speech was greeted with applause. (Havas)
SPORT AND PLAY
Cricket
A.C.C. v. H.M.S. Carnarvon

Played at Alexandria on Saturday, December 2, the club winning by ten wickets. Messers Preston and Weedon were in great form, while the visitors -several of their best players being absent- were unable to make much of a stand against the bowling of Messrs. Thurston and Byrne.
A.C.C
Mr. Preston not out 109
" Weeden not out 50
" Byrne
" T.C. Maucouley
" Thurston
" Ash
" Freeman did not bat
" Lester
" Law
" Maltass
" Sheperd
Byes 2, leg bye 1 3
Innings declaredd closed 162

row.cell: Mr. Edmonds c. and b. Thurston

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart
BELFOUR CABINET RESIGNS
"C.B." Summoned By The King
London, December 4
It is expected that Mr. Belfour will be received by the King today. Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman also arrives here today accompanied by the Liberal Whip. (Reuter)
London, December 4
Sir Henry Campbel Bannerman is in town, and it is understood that he accepts the premiership today.
(Later).Sir Henry CAmpbell Bennerman will be received by the King tomorrow.His Majesty received Mr.Belfour today. The audience lasted 45 minuted.
(Later). The Government has resigned. The King summoned Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman. (Reuter)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Property in Cairo
The residence of Khalil Pasba, in the Islamia quarter of Cairo, has been sold for L.E. 105,000
Collapse of House
A house collasped at Boulse on Sunday night, killing a native called Salem Salama and his daughter. Two other natives were badly injured.
Small Dance
The first small dance of the season at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will take place on Saturday, 16th inst., at 10 pm.
Maria Theresa Dollars
The Finance Ministry has accepted the tender of Messers, S. Arditi and Son for the supply of 43,000 Maria Theresa dollars at the cost of L.E. 0.102 7/8 per dollar.
Fatira (Egypt) Exploring Co. Ltd.
The London Stock Exchange Committee has fixed Deccember 6 as a special settling day in Fatira (Egypt) Exploring Co.- 10,007 Shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 1-7 and 65,008 to 75,007.
Railway Employees

It is hoped that now that the Railway Administration is freed from the stringent financial regulations of the past, some effort will be made to improve the financial position of the employees on the active list of this administration.
Mr. Longworth in Uganda

Nairobi is indeed advancing by leeps and bounds (says the "African World"). Another newspaper is to be started shortly under the title of the Globe Trotter. Mr. Longworth, who has just arrived from cairo with a complete plant, is to be the editor, and, from what we have seen, we have no doubt the paper will be bright and sparkling.
Researchers in Sinai

Professor Flinders Petri has embodied his Sinaitic investigations of last sesson in a highly interesting work, entitled "Researchers in Sinai" which is to be published next February by Mr. John Murray. It will be written in a popular form. There will be some discussions in the book of Exodus, the nummber of the Isrealites, etc.
The "Sphinx"

This popular English weekly society paper, which is now in the thirteenth year of its existence, made its debut for the 1905-6 season on Saturday, and is brighter and more up to date than ever. Our Cairo comtemporary has considerably increased its staff, and has obtained the services of competent correspondant and reporters, who will give full accountes every week of all that is taking place in Egyppt which is likely to prove the interest to its subscribers. The Sphinx intends to give special attention to the reporting of social functions and other events of importance, and has made arrangements to recaive weekly letters from London by a leading Society writer giving an interesting record of the movemnts of Society at home. We wish our contemporary every success for the coming season.
ALM and DS

Dr. Ruffer, CMG., President of the Quartantine Board, delivered a most interesting and instructive lecture on the Desert of Sinai yesterday evening under the auspices of the Alexandria, Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society. The lecture, which was illustrated by a series of excellent lantern slides, thrown on the screen by Mr. Binder, was given in the large class room of St. Andrew's High School, which proved far too small to contain the large number of members and others who attended. Rear Admiral Sir Massie Bloomfield, K.C.M.G., who presided, congratulated the society on having secured the services of such an able lecturer, and Mr. E. B. Gould., I.S.O., at the conclusion, thanked Dr. Ruffer for his interesting account of his travels in the Sinaitis Peninsula, and hoped he would again favor the society with a lecture. We understand Dr. Ruffer aggreed to repeat last night's lesson in Ramieh for the benefit of Ramlehites at an early date.

div.head: Archeological Discovery at Alexandria
div.p: Unearthed at Om Kubbeh

During the querring operations in connecction with the new harbour works at Gabbari by Messrs, Almagia, an interesting tomb has been revealed, at the foot of the hill os Om el Kubebeh, on its NE sides.

The tomb is quite near the sea and in immediate vicinity of some conspicious elevated houses on the summit of the hill. It is cut out o f solid rock like that of the Ptelemaic temple at Catacombs six hundred yards further to the SW. It has an entrance court of twenty feet square from which a flight of half dozen steps in front of which, at their base, stands an alter in situ- lead up to the interior.

The tomb itself is a rectangular building about nine feet square medalliiions, nine squares in each row, each square measureing about a foot each way. Thesemeddallions have apperently containedd portraites or pictures, but there are for the most part, now undistinguishable. The plaster of the walls is also painted and decorated, but much of this has suffered either from time or at the hands of the quarrymen.

Members of Alexandria Archeological Society or athers interested in such matters should lose no time n paying a visit to the tomb, as it stands in such a position as to make it impossible to preserve it, in view of the wors being carried out, and its removal is only a question of a few days, during which it is hoped that steps will be taken by MunicipalMuseum Committee to have an accurate drawing of it.

div.head: Reduction in Custom Dues
div.p: We understand that the 4 percents reduction in the import duty on cattle and sheep, which will take effect from 1st January next, applies to carcasses and meat as well as to living animals. It will be interesting to see whether this reduction will have any effect on prices.

div.head: Resignations of Officials
div.p: Mr. Clowes, Inspector of Irrigation. Upper Egypt, has resigned his post. This resignation will take effect from June,1906.
Colonel Friend, RE. Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, has also resigned his post, his resignation to take effect from next January.

div.head: The Grand Cadi
div.p: Numerous rumours are afloat as to the causes of the retirement of the Grand Cadi, Sheikh Yehis, from his post. According to the most wide spread of the reports, the sheikh was unable to satisfy his Imperial masteer as to the attitude he had adopted towards the affair of marriage of Sheik Ali Youseff, Editor of the "Mosad"", with lady Sofia, daughter of Sheikh el Saadat. The Cadi appears to have failed to explain his action to the Sultan in a satisfactory manner, and had no other recourse but to offer his resignation, which was accepted. Another rumour states that the Grand Cadi arregated himself to a position of influence in the Wakfs Administration which were quite incompatible with those of H.H. the Khedive. We give both stories for that they are worth.

div.head: New Banks for Egypt
div.p: As will be recalled ( says the "Daily Mail"), there have been developments in the Egyptian banking world during the last few months, and there is even talk to the effect that the new Egyptian banking concern expected out in the late autumn,and which was deferred, will be heard of again early next year. Meantime it is noteworth that the Wiener Bankverein intends to start banking operations in Egypt shortly.Early in January, we understand, two new Turkish branches will be opened, and then the question of Extending branches to Alexandria and Cairo is to take practical shape. It is onlylatterly that this concer, which has its head office in Vienna, extended itself beyond Autro Hungarian dominions. It has a paid capital of £3,333,000 and reserve funds of nearly £1,000,000.

div.head: Public Works Department
div.p: The tenders of the following contractors have been accepted for canal, drain and dyke earth works in the Minieh and Beni Souef provinces:-

row.cell: Minieh West of Nile T. Yanni and Bochra Hanna

div.head: Penny Postage
div.p: Extended to Egypt and Sudan
London, December 4
In view of the exceptional relations between his Majesty's Government and that of the Khedive, it has been arranged to extend the penny postage to Egypt and Sudan from the 15th instant. (Reuter)

In conformity with Article 21 of the Treaty of the Postal Union, signed at Washing on 15th June, 1897, an arrangement has just been concluded between the United Kingdom and Egypt by which letters from Great Britain to Egypt and the Sudan will be prepaid one penny for every half ounce and letters from egypt and the Sudan to the United Kingdom will be prepaid 5 milliemes for every 15th inst. In notifying the above arrangement to the International Bureau at Berne, the Postnaster General of Egypt state that he authorized by the Khedivve's government to enter into similar arrangements with any other country that would be willing to offer reciprocity.

It will be interesting in this connection to note that the number of letters sent to the United Kingdom from Egypt in the course of a year is 800,000, while letters from the UK to Egypt number 1,000,000.
Lord Cromer and Saba Pasha, the Postmaster General, deserve the heartiest congratulations on the happy issue of the negotiations which have preceded this much desired postal reform.

div.head: The Turkish Crisis
div.p: The complete silence of Reuter's Agency in regard to the position of affairs in Turkey and the doings of the international fleet, is considered very significant. The last Reuter's telegram on the subject published in Egypt was dated Motylene, November 29. and was published in Egypt on Reuter's telegram on the proceedings of the international fleet has appeared in print.

div.head: Egypt and Arabia
div.p: Our Berlin contemporary "Deutsche Worte" recently made the statement in an article's entitled "England and Arabia" that the injured relatives of the pro Turkish Grand Charil of Mecca did not complain of their treatment to the Sultan at Constantinople but to Lord Cromer at Cairo, and made the deduction that England was supporting a movement for Arab unity and independence which had the support of many prominent members of Al Ashar.

We understood that the statement of the late Grand Charif Ann El Rafik have indeed attempted to obtain Britich support both in Egypt and else where to enable them to gain personal ends, but they never sought nor will they obtain any political support whatever from British Government or its representatives.

div.head: The Ghizeh Railway Accident
div.p: An enquiry heldat the Ministry of Public Works has shown conclusively that the Irrigation Department was in no way responsible for the accident near Abou Noumros. The basin embankment did not burst suddenly, as was at first supposed, but suffered from the effects of infiltration, which mined into its bare and finally broke through.

div.head: Notes From Saukin
div.p: (From our Correspondant)
Saukin, November 20

Miralai Macarley Bey, R. E., director of Sudan Railways, accompanied by Ksimakam Sowerby Bey, Chief Engineer, Ways and Works, arrived here by special train from khartoum and Athara on the 25th inst; by the same train the Governor also arrived.

div.head: Steamer Movements
div.p: The S.S. Trojan Prince left Manchesteron Monday and is due at Alexandria via Tonis and Malta, on December 19th

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.
THE HAMIDIEH-HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
INCEPTION OF THE SCHEME.
STATISTICAL FACTS.
(From our Beyrout Correspondent).
[No, I]

On the initiation of the Hedjaz Railway scheme expressions of derision and doubt arose from all quarters, and some of the serious papers of Europe held that this colossal enterprise was doomed to failure. Their view was based on the fact of the insolvency of the Turkish treasury, and the unreliability of Turkish methods as illustrated in the results of the past and existing maladministration. But these practical seers failed to take into account, in their self-complacent predictions, an element which is mightier than the sword or gold, for without it there are so many pieces of inert matter, and it constitutes the soul thereof. This element is religious Zealand solidarity controlled by a masterly spirit. In every human breast this force, all the more mighty because unseen, and untrammeled by the limitations of measurable matter, lies latent, and he who can stir it into active life, and can weld its myriad manifestations into one harmonious common action, is the man who makes world-conquests, whether peaceful or warlike, and hands his name to posterity as a hero.

The great events of history were simply the outcome of a great idea inspired into millions of hearts and materialized by united action. Sultan Abdul Hamid, as the conceiver of the great Pan-Islamic idea and the originator of the Hedjaz railway scheme, as a tangible expression of the great idea, now claims a place among the great men of the world. It was with nothing short of genius that he worked into the loose body of Islam the leaven of the Pan-Islamic federation. Behold the scattered millions of Moslems now rallying around the inevitable banner, more potent than once the Green Flag. Indeed the Hamidieh-Hedjaz railway is only a concrete manifestation of the power that the great idea brought out into life, a determining cause for the union of Islam – a rallying point of the gathering of its scattered legions.

The Zaidis may continue their guerilla warfare, the Druses of Hanran may renew it, and they may, indeed win a victory or so, but throne of Abdul Hamid in Constantinople will stand and can alone be a fit representative of Moslem power and sovereignty. The Arab is too essentially a nomad, and too much out of the way, in an arid country hardly in touch with the civilized world, while he is too ignorant of modern methods and the diplomatic science, and far inferior to the Turk in that cosmopolitan versatility which has played for centuries with European statesmanship, to be able to take his stand with the Sovereigns of Europe and fitly and worthily represent the vast empire of Islam in the international councils of the world. And the more the Moslem gets educated the stronger will be his sense of pride; he will be satisfied only with the sovereign of a great dynasty, that can take, and has, indeed, taken equal rank with the crowned rulers of Christendom.

It would be idle to discuss the Hedjaz railway from an economic standpoint. Save for the Caiffa Dara branch, which crosses the fertile plain of Jazreel Marj Ion Amir – and part of the Jordan Valley – Bi Ghor – the line traverses through a great part of its length arid tracts that have not even commercial possibilities. Indeed it has never been designed as a commercial line. The Imperial initiator meant it from the beginning as an essentially Moslem undertaking to be realized in great part by Moslem money freely given, inasmuch as it was to serve eventually as a great iron link between the millions of Faithful from distant realms, and a means of bringing them together to that spot for which the soul of every Moslem longs- the centre form which Islam sprung and conquered the world. The mainspring of the idea may have been strategical, but it has been kept in the background so as, presumably, not to mar the noble and inspiring idea of Moslem brotherhood by bloody shadows of war.

To get all the necessary funds the Sultan could not tax his subjects, as the Christians in his Empire are not a small minority and they have scarcely any interest in the under taking, altho’ he did impose a tax destined for the Hamidieh Railway, but only to contribute partly to the large funds needed. With his keen intelligence, however he could raise vast sums in other ways, and this by appeal to which all of the Moslems of the world could not but respond. Indeed the Sultan with masterly touch struck the sensitive chord in the great heart of Islam, and like a great psychologist, exploited the two great feelings that underlie human action, and that lay at the root of the great movements of history, viz, the religious instinct and worldly vanity. Those who could not respond to the religious emotion he attracted by decorations, and from all the corners of the world gold flowed into the coffers of the Imperial Company, and with right royal munificence in many cases. India, China, Egypt, Zanzibar, and wherever Moslems exists in Africa, Asia and Eastern Europe – all countries offered their contributions as on sacred altar of sacrifice.

The Finance Department of the Hamidieb Heljaz Railway has just published its balance sheet for the ending July 1903, and I extract the following interesting figures. The total income of the Hamidieh Railway up to the end of that year amounted to 208,928,914 pistres, at 100 pastres the Turkish pound of about 23 francs. This in great part consisted of donations. It comprises also the net proceeds of the sale of the skins of sheep sacrificed in Ramadan on the sacred hill
near Mecca, the new Hedjaz railway tax, appropriations from the agricultural banks, and profits resulting from the exchange of silver coinage

div.head: Irrigation Engineering
div.p: VH

Yet another method of constructing sub aqueous work was a few years ago applied in Egypt to the construction of two important weirs down stream of the Delta barrage. Cement used in the form of grout, for cementing together materials under water, had been successfully used in various ways by different engineers, and notibly in the Hermitage Break water, Jersey, by the late system attracted the attention of the irrigation officials in Egypt and eventually led to its adoption for the weirs. The core and footing walls up to the level of water in the river, and also the foundations of the locks associated with the weirs, were formed under water by the cement grout system. A trench was first dredged across the river bed to the dimensions and levels of the weir cross section. The two walls of the weir were then formed of a continuous succession of block from side to side of the river by means of bottomless "boxes" put together in the dredged trench with the help of floating plant.

div.head: Ramadan and Business
div.p: The "Times" Constantinople Correspondent, writing on November 18, stated that M. Naus, the Belgian Director General of the Parisian Customs, who had come there to conduct the negotiations for the revision of the Treaty of Commerce between Persia and Turkey. Found it impossible to make any headway with this task durng the month of Ramadon, and had left Constantinople on a short visit to Belgium. He expects to return on or about December 6, when the fast will be over and the negotiations can be begun in earnest. The servian delegates wo were in Constantinople to revise the treaty with Servia also found their work retarded by the discinclination of the Turks to do any work in the Ramadan. They were, however, making progress, though slowly, and the negotiations were expected to be concluded before the end of the month.

div.head: The Sleeping Sickness Peril
div.p: Lieutenant Colonel Hayes Sadler, in his report on the Uganda Protectorate for 1904-5, states that the fishing population of the Vistoria Nyanza is rapidly becoming extinct from sleeping sickness. No remedy had been found for the disease, which continued un-bated during the year in the Lake regions of Uganda and Busoga. With the exception of the Nile Province. Sleeping sickness appears to have confined itself to the Lake regions, a belt about ten miles in depth round the Victoria Nyanza, where it first appeared and here and on the adjacent islands the mortality has been appalling, over, 100,000 of the people in these districts having been carried off within the last four years.Latterly, the disease has begun to attack Europeans.

div.head: Egyptian Cotton in Uganda
div.p: In Uganda Egyptian cotton does not appear to thrive as well as American. Severale experiments have been commenced in the protectorate with cotton, several varieties of which are undergoing trial, and the results already obtained indicate that the American Upland cotton will probably be found more suitable for cultivation in Uganda than Egyptian varieties. Severl tons of Egyptian seed were distributed to planters and natives for trial, but the American Upland seems to do better than any of these and furnishes cotton of longer staple than in its native country. Arrangements are in progress to obtain trained pupils from the Indian Agricultural Colleges to instruct the natives the proper methods of cotton cultivation.

div.head: Speculation in American Yarn
div.p: The manipulations in the American cotton market are having a serious effect upon Lancashire's staple industry. The present rates in the raw material are higher than they have been for a considerable time in the past, and the fear is expressed that they will be increased still further by continued manipulation. Trade in American kinds has been poor for some moments owing largely to the cotton situation, but things have got to such a pass that already there is talk of shutting down for a few weeks in the Oldham and South Lancashire districts where cop twist is spun.

Last week a sub committee of the Federation met, and the question of a lessened consuption of cotton to circumvent the bulls and to lessen the output of yarn was mentioned. It is probable the another meeting will be held in order to prepare a report for the general committee of the Federation. The whole situation is looked upon as serious. The New York market is now, it is said, fully controlled by bulls, Mr. Theodore Price having joined them. We made a grave statement that the Washington Bureau estimate, to be issued this week, will be doctored to suit political exigence.

div.head: In Love with Death
div.p: Mr. W.T. Stead, who saw Count Tolstoy when he was in Russia, records in the "Review of Reviews Annual," that the novelist declared to him:"I regret every moment in which I do not feel I am dying. The thought of death is growing to increasingly pleasant that I need to struggle against the fascination of its approach. If I did not believe that I should see sone advance, however slight, towards the coming of the kingdom of God, I would hang myself."

div.head: Cheap Prepaid Advertisements

The address is counted. The advertisement must appear on conseontive days for above rates to be obtained. 50% extra is charged for advertisements not appearing consecutively.

All such advertisements must be prepaid, and to this rule no exception whatever will be made. Letters in reply to advertisements will be posted to any address if a few stamps are sent by the advertiser to cover postage.

div.p: Notice

The Egyptian State Railways Administration has the honor to inform the Public that, commencing from Friday, December 1st, Kagoug station, situated between Kom Ombo and Silwa, will be opened for PAssenger and Goods service, similar to other stations on this line.
Cairo, 30th November 1905. 26847-1

div.head: General Post Office
div.p: From the 15th instant, the postage on letters for the United Kingdom will be reduced and fixed at 5 milliemes for every 15 grams. On the same date, the panny postage will be put in force in the UK for letter to Egypt.
-Alexandria, the 5th December, 1905 26858-1

div.head: The Alexandria Market Company, Ltd.
div.p: Notice is hereb given that the Ordinary General Meeting of the Shareholders in the above Company will be held at the Office of the undersigned on Thursday, 14th December instant, at 4 p.m, for the purpose of:
1. Receiving the accounts and the Report of the Directors for the year ended 31st October last, and declaring a dividend.
2. Electing a Director for the ensuing year.
3. Electing an Auditor for the ensuing year.

The Holders of Share Warrants intending to vote at this meeting are requested to deposit such with the Anglo Egyptian Bank, Limited, here or at the office of the undersigned on or before the 11th instant.
By order of the Directors,
James Hewat, Manager
Alexandria, 5th December 1905. 26859-1
